President Backs
WUS Fund Drive;
"Ugly Men" Run
Dr. Lowell J. Reed, president
of the University, this week issued
a statement backing the forthcoming campus fund drive of the
World University Service, April
22-29, for the benefit of college students all over the world.
Dr. Reed said, in a letter to the
leaders of the drive, "Your purpose of helping each other help
themselves is an excellent one...
continue your work and you will
find satisfactions in many ways."
Final plans for WUS Week on
campus were being formulated this
week by Paul Niebanck and Edgar
Johnson, co-chairmen of the WUS
Advisory Committee.

Discrepancies Uncovered
In Registrar's Voting List
New student government elections for all offices must be held
May 3 and 4, retiring Student Council President Jim Phinney said
last night.
The original balloting on Tuesday and Wednesday of this
week was contested by a student who was eligible but not permitted
to vote because of an error in the list of eligible students furnished
to the SC by the Registrar's Office.
When the lists were checked by Phinney, several discrepancies
were found including one individual who was permitted to vote but
who was in reality ineligible. Under these circumstances, Phinney,
after meeting with the senior members of the Executive Committee
of th Student Council issued the following statement:

Executive Committee Statement

-

"Due to the receipt of a valid protest against the elections and
to subsequent discovery of illegal voting procedure in all three
classes, the senior members of the Executive Committee of the SC
hereby resolve that this election is invalid and that a new election
will be held at the earliest possible time. This committee shall be
responsible for arranging and holding this re-election.
"Due to the inconvenience caused by this re-election and the
forseen extra cost of posters and the like, that would incur, this committee hereby prohibits the display of any campaigning publicity,
posters, buttons, calendars, etc.
"The elections will be held Tuesday, May 3 and Wednesday,
May 4. On Wednesday, April 27, preceding the elections there will
be posted on the Registrar's bulletin board, on the Gillman Hall
board, and the dormitory bulletin board, a list of the names of all
students eligible to vote in their respective classes. All students are
warned to check these lists and if it is felt that there is a discrepancy in their class listings, they shall report to the Registrar's Office and receive, if they have a valid discrepancy, a written statement of change in class listing which they shall present at the polls
in order to be able to vote in their proper class. The decision of
the Registrar's Office will be final.
Respectfully submitted,
Edward Habermann
Jim Phinney

Dr. Morgan Develops
Astronomical Camera
An electronic camera has been
developed by Dr. Russell H. Morgan, head of t h e Department of
Radiology at the Johns Hopkins
School of Medicine, which has
given "unsurpassed photographs of
Mars" in its preliminary tests at
the Lowell Observatory in Flagstaff, Arizona.
The camera, created in conjunction with the Bureau of Ships of
the Navy, is an adaption of the
electronic x-ray developed by Morgan and Ralph Sturm. Essentially
a closed circuit television system,
the advantage of the instrument is
that it not only reproduces the image, but also intensifies it many
times and increases the contrast between blacks and whites.
Lowell Observatory announced,
after its tests, "Modifications of the
camera which are now being made
may make it possible to detect features on the surface of Mars which
have never been observed before."
Increases Brightness
Besides intensifying the image,
the camera also increases the
brightness to a point where it can
virtually "see in the dark." It is
twenty five times more light sensitive than a camera, according to
Morgan, Photographic film utilizes
less than one half of one percent of

the available light, whereas Morgan's invention can make use of ten
percent of the light. In effect, this
would increase the effectivenesse of
the two hundred-inch telescope of
Mount Palomar to one of one-thousand inches with the intensifier.
Dr. John D. Strong, professor of
meteorology and physics at the Hop(Continued on Page 5)

Council Suggests Changes
In Grade Posting System
Possible changes in the final
grade posting procedure were reported to the Student Council last
week.
The Council accepted a four-point
report which was made by a Committee, which consisted of Ed Habermann and Bob Mitgang. The four
points which the Committee suggested were:
1—The names of those people passing a course will be posted, but no
grades will appear on the sheet.
Students must see their instructor
to obtain their final grades.
2—Each student will bring a
white card with him, upon swhich
he will place his name and his post
office box number. His grade will

Faulty Procedure
Invalidates Voting;

be marked on this card and the
card will be placed in his box.
3—Each student will bring an
addressed post card to the exam and
it will be mailed to him as soon as
the grades are compiled.
4—Each paper which is handed
out will have a number written
upon it. The student will add his
name to the paper and he will record the exam number. His final
exam grade and his grade for the
course will be posted next to his
number once the grades are decided.

We Need Your Head In Our
Business

Bob Larimer Elected
New IFB President
Bob Larimer of DU was elected
Inter-Fraternity Board President
for the '55-'56 school year in last
week's IFB elections.
Also elected were Vice-President,
Rowland - King, Phi Gam; Secretary-Treasurer, Norman Vander
Noot, KA; and Recorder, Howard
Waskow, A.EPi.
Joe Veverka, outgoing IFB president, had this to say about the new
officers: "I think the officers
chosen for next year are excellent
choices by the board and I am sure
they will do a splendid job." Veverka pointed out that Bob Larimer
was Vice-President of the IFB two
years ago and along with the other
new officers is well versed in the
problems confronting the IFB.
Veverka then said, "I would like
to say that this year's board has
cooperated very well and I think
the fraternities have benefited
through its actions.

of the Republic".

After having their Wednesday
match with Gettysburg College
postponed, the Hopkins Blue Jays
will travel to Newark, Delaware,
tomorrow to cross racquets with
the University of Delaware Blue
Hens.
Although JHU won its opening
match from American University
by an 8-1 count, Coach Fred Steinmann has been putting his Blue
Jay netmen through strenuous
workouts this past week. The
boys have been working hard at
improving their strokes, and have
been trying to get that extra zip
in their serves.
With the addition of former
frosh star Ira Anderson to the
team, the competition has become
tougher for singles berths. Senior
Ed Habermann is, at present, the
number one man on the squad,
with junior Al Greenberg in the

number two slot. In a practice
match last Tuesday, they split sets,
Greenberg winning the opener, 6-1,
and Habermann taking the final,
6-3. Right behind Habermann and
Greenberg is Ron Creamer, who
has impressed Coach Steinmann
with his early season play. Sophomore Dan Switky played in the
number four spot in the American
University match, and, although he
was beaten in a tough three set
match, he showed Steinmann some
good form and powerful strokes.
Switky has been working all
week to work out some of the weak
shots in his game, and as the JHU
mentor said, "With a little confidence, Danny could be one of the
better players in the conference."
Another player who has impressed Steinmann with his play'
so far this season is soph Herb
Butler. Butler plays "the good,
'
steady, consistent type of tennis,'
and he "rarely makes a bad shot."
Two other sophomores have
shown Steinmann that they can
play a good game of tennis. Joe
Pedorella and Claude Barfield, who
teamed up to play third doubles
against American U., have "im"
proved quite a bit from last year'
and have bright futures in Hopkins tennis, according to the Jay'
coach. Another leading contender
for a front line singles berth is
Junior Pete Bower.

Discrepancies Uncovered
In Registrar's Voting List
New student government elections for all offices must be held
May 3 and 4, retiring Student Council President Jim Phinney said
last night.
The original balloting on Tuesday and Wednesday of this
week was contested by a student who was eligible but not permitted
to vote because of an error in the list of eligible students furnished
to the SC by the Registrar's Office.
When the lists were checked by Phinney, several discrepancies
were found including one individual who was permitted to vote but
who was in reality ineligible. Under these circumstances, Phinney,
after meeting with the senior members of the Executive Committee
of th Student Council issued the following statement:

Executive Committee Statement

-

"Due to the receipt of a valid protest against the elections and
to subsequent discovery of illegal voting procedure in all three
classes, the senior members of the Executive Committee of the SC
hereby resolve that this election is invalid and that a new election
will be held at the earliest possible time. This committee shall be
responsible for arranging and holding this re-election.
"Due to the inconvenience caused by this re-election and the
forseen extra cost of posters and the like, that would incur, this committee hereby prohibits the display of any campaigning publicity,
posters, buttons, calendars, etc.
"The elections will be held Tuesday, May 3 and Wednesday,
May 4. On Wednesday, April 27, preceding the elections there will
be posted on the Registrar's bulletin board, on the Gillman Hall
board, and the dormitory bulletin board, a list of the names of all
students eligible to vote in their respective classes. All students are
warned to check these lists and if it is felt that there is a discrepancy in their class listings, they shall report to the Registrar's Office and receive, if they have a valid discrepancy, a written statement of change in class listing which they shall present at the polls
in order to be able to vote in their proper class. The decision of
the Registrar's Office will be final.
Respectfully submitted,
Edward Habermann
Jim Phinney

Dr. Morgan Develops
Astronomical Camera
An electronic camera has been
developed by Dr. Russell H. Morgan, head of t h e Department of
Radiology at the Johns Hopkins
School of Medicine, which has
given "unsurpassed photographs of
Mars" in its preliminary tests at
the Lowell Observatory in Flagstaff, Arizona.
The camera, created in conjunction with the Bureau of Ships of
the Navy, is an adaption of the
electronic x-ray developed by Morgan and Ralph Sturm. Essentially
a closed circuit television system,
the advantage of the instrument is
that it not only reproduces the image, but also intensifies it many
times and increases the contrast between blacks and whites.
Lowell Observatory announced,
after its tests, "Modifications of the
camera which are now being made
may make it possible to detect features on the surface of Mars which
have never been observed before."
Increases Brightness
Besides intensifying the image,
the camera also increases the
brightness to a point where it can
virtually "see in the dark." It is
twenty five times more light sensitive than a camera, according to
Morgan, Photographic film utilizes
less than one half of one percent of

the available light, whereas Morgan's invention can make use of ten
percent of the light. In effect, this
would increase the effectivenesse of
the two hundred-inch telescope of
Mount Palomar to one of one-thousand inches with the intensifier.
Dr. John D. Strong, professor of
meteorology and physics at the Hop(Continued on Page 5)

Council Suggests Changes
In Grade Posting System
Possible changes in the final
grade posting procedure were reported to the Student Council last
week.
The Council accepted a four-point
report which was made by a Committee, which consisted of Ed Habermann and Bob Mitgang. The four
points which the Committee suggested were:
1—The names of those people passing a course will be posted, but no
grades will appear on the sheet.
Students must see their instructor
to obtain their final grades.
2—Each student will bring a
white card with him, upon swhich
he will place his name and his post
office box number. His grade will

Faulty Procedure
Invalidates Voting;

be marked on this card and the
card will be placed in his box.
3—Each student will bring an
addressed post card to the exam and
it will be mailed to him as soon as
the grades are compiled.
4—Each paper which is handed
out will have a number written
upon it. The student will add his
name to the paper and he will record the exam number. His final
exam grade and his grade for the
course will be posted next to his
number once the grades are decided.

Bob Larimer Elected
New IFB President
Bob Larimer of DU was elected
Inter-Fraternity Board President
for the '55-'56 school year in last
week's IFB elections.
Also elected were Vice-President,
Rowland - King, Phi Gam; Secretary-Treasurer, Norman Vander
Noot, KA; and Recorder, Howard
Waskow, A.EPi.
Joe Veverka, outgoing IFB president, had this to say about the new
officers: "I think the officers
chosen for next year are excellent
choices by the board and I am sure
they will do a splendid job." Veverka pointed out that Bob Larimer
was Vice-President of the IFB two
years ago and along with the other
new officers is well versed in the
problems confronting the IFB.
Veverka then said, "I would like
to say that this year's board has
cooperated very well and I think
the fraternities have benefited
through its actions.

After having their Wednesday
match with Gettysburg College
postponed, the Hopkins Blue Jays
will travel to Newark, Delaware,
tomorrow to cross racquets with
the University of Delaware Blue
Hens.
Although JHU won its opening
match from American University
by an 8-1 count, Coach Fred Steinmann has been putting his Blue
Jay netmen through strenuous
workouts this past week. The
boys have been working hard at
improving their strokes, and have
been trying to get that extra zip
in their serves.
With the addition of former
frosh star Ira Anderson to the
team, the competition has become
tougher for singles berths. Senior
Ed Habermann is, at present, the
number one man on the squad,
with junior Al Greenberg in the

number two slot. In a practice
match last Tuesday, they split sets,
Greenberg winning the opener, 6-1,
and Habermann taking the final,
6-3. Right behind Habermann and
Greenberg is Ron Creamer, who
has impressed Coach Steinmann
with his early season play. Sophomore Dan Switky played in the
number four spot in the American
University match, and, although he
was beaten in a tough three set
match, he showed Steinmann some
good form and powerful strokes.
Switky has been working all
week to work out some of the weak
shots in his game, and as the JHU
mentor said, "With a little confidence, Danny could be one of the
better players in the conference."
Another player who has impressed Steinmann with his play'
so far this season is soph Herb
Butler. Butler plays "the good,
'
steady, consistent type of tennis,'
and he "rarely makes a bad shot."
Two other sophomores have
shown Steinmann that they can
play a good game of tennis. Joe
Pedorella and Claude Barfield, who
teamed up to play third doubles
against American U., have "im"
proved quite a bit from last year'
and have bright futures in Hopkins tennis, according to the Jay'
coach. Another leading contender
for a front line singles berth is
Junior Pete Bower.
